intro: Scleria salebrosa, commonly known as the yellow-eyed grass, is a member of the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and grasses. It is a perennial plant characterized by its slender, triangular stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in dense, spike-like clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Scleria salebrosa is often found in wet or moist habitats such as marshes, swamps, and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, contributing to soil stabilization and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
